THE BLACKSMITH; or A Day a t Gretna Green.

8.- l t o m n l u a , f r o m D a v i d ' . P i c t u r e o f t h e S a b i n e . . \2.—The D y i n g Gladiator.

D U N

TWO NECKS

St. PAUL'S, from Ludgate Street, w i t h Two Obelisks, by Lamplight.

*

Which he will pourtr&y upon a Pedestal in the centre of the Stage. This arrangement is made, in order to convey to the classical taste of Artists, in a*
effective manner, a series of the beautiful compositions of Ancient Sculpture, the fidelity of which will be recognised by every connoisseur, as they are
studied from Casts and Drawings of the very best authorities. The following is the order of the portraiture :-»-

.'.—The F i g h t i n g Gladiator, In T h r e e b e a u t i f u l
Position..
f;.—The African a l a r m e d a t the T h u n d e r .

RE-APPEARANCE,

Having on Tuesday attracted one of the most crowded and brilliant
Audiences of the Season, t h e Public Is respectfully informed, that
it will h e repeated THIS EVENING, TO-MORROW, and SATURDAY,
being positively t h e LAST BIGHTS i t earn he performed for a very
considerable time, in consequence of t h e many forthcoming Novelties.
Ort Monday, Mr. SHERIDAN KNOWLES will perform M A C B E T H * »«> **»* appearance in that Character for
a comidirable period: Macduff, Mr. Abbott, Banquet, Mr. Eg-erton, Lady Macbeth, Mrs. Eg«rton.

RE-APPEARANCE,

Having on Tuesday a t t r a c t e d one of the most erowded and brilliant
Audiences of t h e Season, t h e Public is respectfully informed, t h a t
It w i l l he repeated on FRIDAY and SATURDAY, being positively the
LAST! NIGHTS it ean he performed for a very considerable time, in
consequence of the many forthcoming Novelties.
On Monday, Mr. SHERIDAN KNOWLES will perform M A C B E T H , bis last appearance in that Character for
a constderable feriod: Macduff, Mr. Abbott, Banquo, Mr. Egerton, Lady Macbeth, Mrs. Eg* rton.
On Tuesday, will be produced, with new and extensive Scenery, an entirely new Malo-Drama, in Three Actt, to be called

MOUNT ST. B E R N A R D S

of this highly popular P l a y

To TEN

in consequence of

Royal,

and

POLISH

The Managers of the ROYAL VICTORIA THEATRE having agreed
to give an Entertainment, solely a t their own Risk and Expense.
THIS EVENING, WEDNESDAY,
for t h e Benefit of t h e POLISH
EXILES, on Terms of unparalleled Liberality, in which they will be
supported b y distinguished Musical and Dramatic Talent, the Cam*
mittee of the " POLISH EXILES' FRIEND SOCIETY" e a r n e s t l y solicit
the Patronage of the Public on their Sehalf.
S y Order ef the Committee,
SANFORD A R N O T , Hon. Sec.

PKICE.

NO S E C O N D

PKICE.

Mr. ABBOTT and Mr. EGERTON,
in announcing a reduction of the Prices of Admission to the BOXCM. Pit and Gallery of the Victoria,
do not veil lure, in any degree, to offer the Attraction as a boon to their Patrons. Their motive is
solely a commercial one, based upon the just principle that, whatever the Public may consider most
to its advantage, must contribute more certainly to the success of those whose occupation is to cater
for its amusement.

PESTHOYED.

Mademoiselle R O S I E R , Don Guzman (the Commandant)

NO SECOND

Old Woma, Mr HEATH

At the same tim>, they may be allowed, with some satisfaction to say of the past, that,
commencing under discouragements nearly unparalleled in Theatrical History, they have made
ir.auv strenuous endeavours towards rendering the Victoria a National Establishment, a Refuge for
the Genius, both of the Aufhor and the Actor. Most of these attempts have been rewarded by the
unequivocal hanctioti of the Public, and the warm support of the popular and discriminating organ
of its opinion—the Press.
.
|
MrABBO I T and Mr. EGRRTON* pledge themselves, with the Alteration, to renewed exertions,
both as to Plays and Performers T h e style of Entertainment which they have sought to foster
has been what may be. most/properly comprised in the term the Legitimate Drama; by it they have
at least offered the opportunity of ailherrihg to correct taste and the best uses of the Stage ; te the
same purposes they will still moj.t ardently devote themselves.
Mr. A B B O T T and Mr. EGRRTON reserve to themselves the right, on all rSocasions, when an
outlay must be incurred which the reduced Prices may not, with any reasonable probability meet.
Of returning to the ones jately charged ; and the same exception is made for the Benefits of the
Performers
"i

The Piece will conclude with

A V i e w of t h e I n f e r n a l R e g i o n s ,

Mr. A B B O T T and Mr. E G E R T O N ,
i« announcing a reduction o f t h e Prices o f Admission t o the Boxes. Pit and Gallery o f the Victoria,
d o not venture, in any d e g r e e , t o offer the Attraction 'as a boon t o their Patrons- T h e i r motive i s
solely a commercial one, based upon t h e j u s t principle that, whatever t h e P u b l i c may consider most
to its advantage, must contribute mors certainly t o the success o f those whose occupation is t o cater
fer its amusement. '
A t t h e same time, t h e y may b e allowed, with some satisfaction t o say o f t h e past, that,
commencing under discouragements nearly unparalleled in Theatrical History, t h e y have made
w i n y strenuous endeavours towards rendering the Victoria a National Establishment, a Refuge for
the Genius, both o f t h e A u t h o r and t h e Actor.
Most o f these a t t e m p t s have been rewarded by t h e
unequivocal sanction o f t h e P u b l i c , and t h e warm s u p p o r t of the p o p u l a r and discriminating organ
• f its o p i n i o n — t h e Press.
M r A B B O T T and Mr. E G E R T O N pledge themselves, with the Alteration, t o renewed exertions,
both as to Clays and Performers
T h e style o f Entertainment which they have sought t o foster
has been what may be most properly comprised in t h e t e r m t h e Legitimate D r a m a ; by i t they have
at least ottered the o p p o r t u n i t y o f adhering to correct taste and t h e best uses o f t h e Stage j t e »i»<
mine purposes they will still most ardently devote themselves.
;
Mr* A B B O T T and Mr. E G E R T O N reserve to themselves t h e r i g h t , o n all occasions, when an
• a day m u s t b e i n c u r r e d which the reduced Prices may not, with any reasonable probability meet,
.f r e t u r n i n g t o the ones lately c h a r g e d ; and the same exception i s m a d e for t h e Benefits o f t h e

111 -onotinciu^ » reduction ot the I'rices of Admission to t h e Boxes, Hit and Gallery o f the Victoria,
do not venture, iu any decree, t o offer t h e Attraction as a boon to their Patrons. T h e i r motive is
solely a couiuiemal «ine, based upon t h e just principle that, whatever the P u b l i c may consider most
to its advantage, must contribute mora certainly t o the success uf those whose occupation is t o eater
for i t s amusement.
A t t h e s a m e time, t h e y may b e allowed, with some satisfaction to say o f t h e past, that,
commencing under discouragements nearly unparalleled in Theatrical History, they have made
tnanv strenuous endeavours towards rendering t h e Victoria a National i-stabiisljtne««, a Kefuge Sot
the Genius, both of t h e A u t h o r and t h e Actor.
Most o f these attempts have b e e s rewarded by t h e
unequivocal sanction o f the P u b l i c , and t h e warm s u p p o r t o f the popular and dsscri<n».itting organ
of its opinion—the Press.
M r A U B O T T and Vlr. E G F . U T O N pledge themselves, with t h e Alteration, t o renewed exertions,
b o t h as to Plays and Performers
The s t y l e o f -Entertainment which they h a v e s o u g h t t o foster
has been what may be most properly comprised in t h e term t h e Legitimate D r a m a ; by i t they have
at least offered the o p p o r t u n i t y of a d h e r i n g to correct taste and t h e best uses o f t h e Stage ; M t i e
»*me purposes they will still mo»t ardently devote themselves.

The YOUNG LADY who made her First Appearance on
any Stage, l a s t Evening, in the Character of JULIET,
having heen honoured w i t h the most enthusiastic and
rapturous applause from an elegant and crowded
Audience, never exceeded, even by the brilliant first
appearances of K i s s ONEIL& Miss FANNY KEMBLE, and i t s repetition
having been loudly demanded, it w i l l , therefore, in obedience to the
Public w i s h , so flatteringly expressed, be repeated This EVENING, on
MONDAY N e x t , and Three-Times-a-Week until further Notice.

. The YOUNG LADY who made her Second Appearance on
any Stage, l a s t Evening, [Thursday] in the Character of
JULIET,having been honoured with the most enthusiastic
and rapturous applause from an elegant a n d crowded
Audience, never exceeded, even "by the brilliant first
appearances of Miss OHEIL& Miss FANNY KEMBLE. and i t s repetition
having been loudly demanded, i t w i l l , therefore, in obedience to the
Public wish, s o flatteringly expressed, be repeated on MONDAY n e x t ,
and Three-Times-a-Week until further Notice.

rentirely competed by a Young Lady Seventeen Years of Aye / ] will positively be brought out at the end of January, when it will be produced with an

time here) the admired Play of ELLEN WAREHAM; or. The WIFE of TWO HUSBANDS! Cressforcl, Mr Haines; Capt, Warebam,
Mr Elliott; Algernon Hamilton, Mr Selby ; Dick, Mr Vale ; Pollard, Mr Ross ; Mr Allenham, Mr Bender; Ellen Wareham, MrsSefton;
Matilda, Miss Jutian ; Old Margery, Mrs Garrick; Caroline, Miss Garrick. After which, (Cthtiine) The WEDDING SUPPER. To conclude
with a Melo-Drama, from the French ef St. Amant, to be called The AUBERGE DES ADRETS. Principal Gharacters by Mr Wallack, Mr
Valf, Mr W. Keene, Mr Row, Mr Griffith, Mr Bender, Mrs Selby, Miss Garrick, etc. etc.
On Thursday, (6th time) The Grand Opera of The MAID of JUDAH. Ivanhoe, Mr Collins ; Rebecca, Miss Eliza Paton.
Doors open at Six.

The Intense Interest and the stirring situations that abound in this Piece have tended to rank it among the most effective of this powerful Author's peculiar Dramas. It is now creating a considerable sensation in Paris, and the Proprietor anxious to be the first in presenting Novelty to the Public, has gone to a considerable Expence in Scenery and Dresses in adapting it to the English Stage.
In consequence of the prevailing taste in favour of Foreign Opera, and the present ragefor B E L L I N I ' S O P E R A , O F " L A
S O M N A M B U L A " The Manager has the pleasure to announce another New Version of i t, under the Title of

THE ROOF SCRAMBLER.
On MONDAY, J U N E 15th. and during the Week.

Tha PROPRIETOR fully aware of the necessity of a rapid succession of Novelty, to obtain a continuance of the Public Patronage, as
liberally bestowed, announces

ANOTHER NEW ME LO-DRAMA I
The Piece called

The E C H O of W E S T M I N S T E R B R I D G E

ias been suggested by the Tradition of a Conspiracy that was on the Point of being betrayed by the well-known e o n o from one Recess to another.
in order to suit it to ibe Purposes of the Drama, a powerful Plot of strong Domestic Interest has been interwoven with the main Incident; and Scenery
., on a moat extensive Scale, has been prepared to give due Effect to the Production, in which
Jgfjgg. CttEEUT, MlTCMnBtili, B Q C B B S , Mls» F O S T E R , and M i s . A. C. C R A Y , will sustain the principal Characters.
The new Melo-etraina of

The MINERALI
Martelli, Mr DENYIL,

baa made- a most powerful impression on the Public, and will be repeated e v e r y E v e n i n g u n t i l f u r t h e r - IVotloftj

whose Engagement has been renewed, on account of bis great attraction in this Original Character.
. .,

In the course of the Piece the following n e w S c e n e r y , painted by Mr HILLYARD, will be exhibited :—

OUTSIDE of B O A T - B U I L D E R ' S ,
WITH A SUNSET ¥IEW [taken from the Lambeth Side] OF

W E S T M I N S T E R A B B E Y and H A L L !
INTHKlOli OF BOAT-BUILDUSlVS KITCHEN.

In Act III will be exhibited, a Scene, surpassing in Magnitude, any ever yet presented on the Stage, being a perfect
Model (on a very large Scale) of

WESTMINSTER BRIDGE!
ns seen from Bridge Street; and which, from the great size of the Stage of this Theatre, (known to be, with but one
exception, the largest in London) will, it is expected, produce a COUP D'OEIL never before produced. In this Scene
also will be introduced, a new Effect, by means of an e c h © > never yet applied to the Purposes of the Drama.

TO CONCLUDE WITH A .

\

fcj- In earnestly soliciting the pittronttgo of a hunmne British PwWic, to whom the injured and opprest never appealed in vain,
ami whose kindness Miss C. to often experienced in the hour ^ h e ^ i n w t iw,d, and fyr'Which she do|s, and ever shall retain a
grateful recollection, the begs to.refer to her peculiar and extraordinary ^ase,, with referknee to Mr. O'Cdonell, und earnestly solicits
the calm dispassionate attention of u generous public, to whojfc candour and judgement she appeals, whose strictest enquiry aba
courts, and who ever censure with lenity, a«d reward with liberality.
On Wlv» Courtcnay's enlargement from a Prison where she, had been incarcerated solely for a debt contracted for thi maintenance of Mr. O'Connell's Child '.she set out for Dublin to seek the aforesaid Child, who had been secreted from her, and whom after a
tjjtrSe years search, at length she found him in the utmost wretchedness, sleeping on a dunghill of Straw, in a wretched Stable, where
tho rains of Heaven poured upon him ! his companion an old diseased Horse that was often near killing him; and otherwise so IB
n«d and badly treated, that it wa» shocking to behold him; the Laws restrained them from committing a Murder, but the Intention
ot getting rid of him was obvious! he is wholly tmeducated, in common with the rest of Mr. O'Connell's numerous deserted Children, mony of whom she encountered, and is prepared to provif, ami hopes she will have occasion to do so-^-that Mr. O'Connell, this ,
generous Man!—this great Patriot f not only consigns his unhappy victims to lasting: wretchedness and misery, but also his very
numerous and unoffending offspring, whom he utterly abandons) who are scattered In various parts of Ireland, In filth, nakedness,
distress, and demoralisation, totally uneducated ! on« of whom to herown knowledge, had been sentio a Lunatic Hospital in Dublin,
for having solicited his Father for Uwtneans of support.
•..
; '
If Mr. O'Consell cAn-deny these facts, .why nbt,do ao• "• If he cannot, which he feels in his Soul to be the ease, tbef» is not
a Felon I . any of the; Jails of ih« United Kingdom, tt%t would not blush to be guilty of what he is.
Let Mr, O'ConiieU's hired fagfttmifflns> those cowardly assassins of fame and character, defame, slander, and pour alt their
mnlignant malice and wra^h, upon a defenceless, illused Female,, let them fto please Mr. O'Connell,) murder me and my poor boy,
if they will; I repeat it, 1 %\e never stated a falsehood of Mr. OJConnel}, were I capable of such an act, no punishment inflicted
on me would be to severe; on the contrary*! have endured |4 year's of the most extraordinary cruelty and unheard of suffering,
until at length my seared bi Sin, and goailerrlBelings have brged me to give publicity tq facts, which during that period I have
scrupulously concealed. Had I been the willing* associate of thelheartless libertine, 1 should have ifo right to complain of the *
consequences of my ewta imprudence and fc4ly; but had 1 not a right to complain Pwheft disastrous results, etnaoated from circura
ttances over which 1 had ho controul. , .

Who bus not heard of tbe escape of LATACE from the horrors of the Bastile, in the year 17SB ? The facts, a fall detail of which,
as related by LATUDE himself, will be found in Nos, 28 & 29 of the PENNY MAGAZINE, have been strictly adhered to, in the progress of this Drama ; except where they appeared to task belief too strongly, A reference to the narration will materially increase the interest that must be felt by the spectator, In witnessihg the Intense and breathless Incidents of this piece; which, it is
only surprising, has not lohg before been presented to the public in a dramatic shape.

wS* opposite Page) to be the most striking ever yet produced—it will be repeated every Evening till farther Notice.

The First Performance of " T H E J E W E S S " having, by the Surpassing Beauty of the Scenery, the Matchless Splendour of the Dresses—the
Characteristic Excellence of the Kusic—the Gorgeous Magnificence of the Armour, Banners and Decorations—the Brilliant Arrangements of
the Processions, Ballet and Combats—the Intense Interest of the Incidents and Perfection of the Acting—created the most

ELECTRICAL EFFECT ever felt within the Walls of a Theatre,
Stamping the VICTORIA Second to none in the Metropolis! the whole Spectacle feeing pronounced by the Public and Ae Press (for which
see opposite Page) to be the most striking ever yet produced—it will be repeated every Evening till further Notice.
Orders of every Description will be stopped during the run of The J E WESS, and the Free hist total In suspended, the Press alone excepted^

F r o m t h e Morning Chronicle.
A new piece, called 'The Jewess, written by Mr. ft'oncrieff, and founded on
Scrilie's La Juive, which has obtained great celebrity in Paris, was produced at
this Theatre last night. The plot differs very little Irnu that of the same name
now playing at Drury-lane ; indeed, so little, that we lu 1 it would be a work of
supererogMion for us to go into a description of it. And most grateful are we
to be thus relieved ; for most difficult should we find it to recover our self-possession so as to be able to give a precise narrative embodying the numerous incidents, amazed, as we were, that any piece should be produced on such a grand
scale at a minor, and perfectly bewildered as we were by the beauty of the scenery,
the gorgeousness of the processions, the blasts of the trumpets, the mazes of the
dances, the fearful vigour of the combatants, Sec
No expence lias been spared in
this spirited undertaking, and we are glad to add that its success has been triumphant; the audience testified their approbation in repeated round* of thundering
applause. The proprietor of the Victoria has managed so well on this occasion
that the public will very much question whether they can do these things better
in France. A temporary stage has been made across the pit to increase the geueitil effect. We understand that the procesion, equestrian and foot, occupies a
space of 170 feet, and the corps dramatique consists of nearly 200 persons. The
performers acquitted themselves ?ery creditably. Mr. N. T. Hicks played Prince
Leepold, and, in parti, exceedingly well; unfortunately he is sometimes rather
affected in his pronunciation, but this is a defect which a little pains will remove.
Mr. Archer's Jcto was a very correct and impressive reading. A Mr. Johnstone,
from Brighton, made his first appearance as Karl, and got through the little assigned to him in a manaer that affords considerable promise. A Miss 11. Palmer,
from Exeter, also made herfirstappearance, the character she played being the
Princess Eudosia. This lady exhibited so much talent, notwithstanding that her
opportunity was so very limited, that we hope to see her soon in same pait that
will put her powets fully to the test. She was impassioned without rant, and
throughout natural. Rachel was played by Mrs, Selby with mucu power and
effect."

ROYAL VICTORIA THEATRE.

Sole Proprietor, Mr. L.

Acting and Stage Manager, Mr, C.

LEVY.

HILL.

RICHARD PLAqTAGHNET, w i t h R e a l H o r s e s , R e a l A r m o u r , a n d ISO A u x i l i a r i e s .
If amusement and instruction blended, can constitute a claim to public favour, surely this Spectacle merits the unprecedented success
it has already encountered, and may justly be deemed a most appropriate Drama for the Younger Branches of Society, for whilst
the fate of poor Effie, the heart-rending grief of her Father, and the remorse of the King, her betrayer, cannot fail to strike a
Wholesome Lesson to the heart of youth, the eye is delighted, and the mind relieved and instructed by a faithful picture of
historical facts, and the manners and customs of all classes of society in the chivalrous day of Richard the Second. The Gorgeous
Pajeant and Procession of Walworth, Mayor of London—The Old English Morris and May-pole Dances, and the Brilliantly
Illuminated Tableaux Vivant, have stamped it the most successful Drama of the Day. It will therefore be performed every Evening
during the Holidays.
Children under \'% years of age, admitted at half-price to the Boxes.

On M O N D A Y , J A N U A R Y 3 , 1 S 3 G . & during t h e w e e k .

To Conclude with an entirely New and Original Comic Pantomime, written and invented by Mr. NELSON LEE, entitled

HARLEQUIN

ROBINSON CRUSOE
" Who had a man F r i d a y to keep his, house tidy,

JUVENILE WEEK.

Children under 12 Years of Age, half-price to the Boxes only..
KT BY S P E C I A L D E S I R E .

Of several Little Ladies and Gentlemen, now home for the Holidays, the Performance will commence with the successful Comic Pantomime of H A R L E Q U I N
UOIHNSON CRUSOE, for this week only, when it must be withdrawn, to make room for various novelties, upon amost maccniticem scale now in preparation.

"

~ ~

REDUCTION

OF PRICES.

Tho brilliant success of this, uow, most popular place of amusement, enables the proprietor, with pride and gratitude, to exercise a corresponding share of
liberality, in return for the patronage bestowpd on him by a generous and discerning public ; he has therefore resolved to reduce the admission to the Boxes, from
'I'M R E E S H I L L I N G S to T W O , notwithstandinc the heavy ex|>ence attending Richard Plantoge.net, with Real Hones, lieul A?muur, and 150 Auxiliaries.

The Prices therefore will in future be BOXES 2s.

_-__ Mr.^TINING (from Mad. Vestris's Royal Olympic Theatre.)

<K£* T h e Public is most respectfully informed, that the Lessee of this Establishment, from the Encouragement already bestowed on h i s
efforts, has resolved on sparing neither Pains or Expense in procuring every species of NOVBI.TY for the gratification of his numerous
Putrpiis; and although it is perfectly ttrmessary, from t h e TBIOMPHAKT Success of H A T T I i I N t h e R E E V E R ! to make nnv
addition to the present Arrangements, yet, from the extraordinary a n d unrivalled Performances of the F r e n c h ( g l a d i a t o r s , ! he
has entered into an Engagement with those Artistes, whose astonishing ATHLCTIC PERFORMANCES have created the most Extraordinary
Sensation in various parts of the Continent, b u t more particularly in P a n s , where their Representations have been nightly hailed by the
moat powerful and enthusiastic marks of Approbation.

Every effort has been made, no expense spared by the Proprietor in order to produce the new Historical
Drama of RICHARD PLANTAGENET; or, a Legend of Walworth, on Monday, November 21, every
amriliary aid has been put into requisition—but the extent of the Scenery and Machinery, the number
and splendour of thp Dresses, the Magnitude of the Historical Tableaux, &c. render it his imperative
duty to postpone its production till Wednesday the 23rd, of November, in order that it may then be
presented in a state of perfection never excelled

M o n d a y audi Wiiesclay S o v e m h e P 31st, a n a 22nd,

F O R T H E B E N E F I T OF T H E

DISPENSARY.
Mr PURVIS being wishful to give a Benefit to some Charitable Institution,
he therefore, in consequence of the sickness at the present time in the town,
has been induced to give it to the above; which, he trusts, will meet with
the Approbation and Support of the kind Patrons of the Theatre, and Public
in general.

R o y a l Victoria Theatre.
The Manager has the Honour to announce that he ha; entered into arrangements with

M r . COLLINS, M r . WALLACK & Miss T i R P I I ,
To perform at this most popular place of amusement, Every Wednesday and Friday Night.

Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday, Feb. 20, 21, 23, & 25,
Will be presented, a New and Original Drama, wrilteu expressly for this Establishment, with strong exciting situations, entitled,

THE

POSTILLION;

The Piece written by Mr, J. P. HART, Author of " Either or the Royal Jewess," " The Bayonet," Sec.
"lie Scenery by Mr. C. J. JAMES—The Music composed and arranged by Mr. LEIGH SMITH, Musical Director lo the Establishment.

The Whole produced under the Direction of Mr, CHARLES HILL.

IC "* ' l a s °^ ' " " 1mrf *xet> * *HHect °^ rel,roac*1 t o tn * Dramatic Literature of this Country that our Neighbours. the
..»"«' • * v - * f - - c ' * ' - /
•
• Parisians hfve furnished our Theatres with matter for representation—hetice, the M inor Dramatist hw sank into a
mere Translator or Compiler 'or the British Taste. This could only have arisen from a want of Encouragement on the part of Managers who have to cater for
fte amusement of the Patrons of each Theatre. However effective ornttraetive a Drama may be in Paris, ulteB transplanted to the English stage, its nationalities and adjucts require skill and tact toaccomodate it to the feelings of those who witness its representation. The most successful productions for histrionic
soperiorily have been of purely home creation. The Lasse e of this Theatre is therefore determined to at least prefer Native Efforts i—with this feeling he has
caused a Drama on a popular subject to be prepared, INDEPKNDANT OP FOREIGN PECULIARITIES, and calculated, he hopes, to meet the
approbation of his Patrons.

First Night or. N e w Drama 11
On MONDAY, September 3, 1858, and during the Week,
Will be presented a N E W DRAMA, in Two Act*, written by Mr. JOHN PARRY, with New Scenery, Machinery,
Music, &c. &c, called

THE SMUGGLER'S GIBBET
OR THS

MANIAC M O T H E R !

JMASQURRADIM

On Monday, 29th October, and every evening during the week, Friday excepted, will be performed the successful, new,
grand, romantic, and original Drama, in two acts, wilh new sceneay, dresses, &c. called

E

mm w P V mm w f
mm A mm mm A •

I he career of two young Frenchman forms the basil of this drama. Orphans at an early age, the twin ore-there, alike In person and manners, were fated. In tb»
fi»»t dawn of manhood, to a lasting separation. With nothing but their name and talents they essayed to cli.nb 'he 'united hill of Faroe and Fortune. Each took
* different course, and as opposite was the result; one rached the pinnacle of happiness, whilst the ottmr was cast :nto the depth of misery ; yet ao interwoven was
their destiny, that, though unknown to each other, Erneat had nearly paid the penalty of the indiscretions of Victor. To detail the plot would but impair the
interest of the piece, which, aidtd as il is by Incidents of a novel and startling character, nannot fail to produce an effect that must be responded to in the breast ot
leery auditor, while fraternal affection holds sympathy with our common nature.

the earliest notice will bs given. Those Ladies and Gentlemen who had secured Seats and Tickets, are respectfully informed

THE FIRE QUEEN,
W i l l e x h i b i t h e r A s t o n i s h i n g Feats.
FIRST —She will Forge a Plate of red-hot Iron with her naked Feet, the same as a Blaeksmirh will upen an anvil.
SI-CON D —She will bend a Bar of red-hot Iron with her bare Feet in various shapes and form*.
THIRD —She will pass a B.r of red-hot Iron several times across her Tongue.
i»OUR TH —She will pass a Body of red-het Flaming Fire over her naked Feet and Arms.
wiPTH —She will allow any Person to drop Burning Sealing Wax on her Tongue, A take an impression with a Seal
SIXTH ~-Stn will dip her Feet into red hot Boiling Lead, and Lift a quantity of it with h«r Hands and put it into her Mouth,
and empty it out for the inspection of the Company with various other Astonishing Feats to numerous to mention.

fury, when Roland rushes to his rescue,

On MONDAY, Sept. lOth, 1 8 3 9 , and D u r i n g the W e e k ,
Will be produced in a style of Magnificence far exceeding every former effort, A N E W ORIGINAL GRAND HISTORICAL DRAMA, entitled

KING

HAROLD!

Or, The Battle of Hastings.
T h e D r a m a w r i t t e n (expressly for this Theatre,) by M r . J ; H A I N E S , Author of •• Amine"' " My Pol! and My Partner Joe,"
'« Richard Plantagenet," "Alice Gray," " Armstrong the Shipwright," "&c." The Scenery Entirely New and the most Picturesque and Beautiful
description. Painted by Messrs. C. JAMES and FINLEY. The Splendid Panorama, &c. by Mr. W. TEL BIN, of the Royal Olympic Theatre,
expressly engaged. The Dresses Entirely new from Authorities of the Period and the Magnificent Armour by Mr CANTOR and Miss HAYWARD.
The Machinery by Mr. MOULDS. The Properties, Banners, Ancient Casques, &c by Mr. PURVIS, from the Theatre Royal, Drnry Lane. The Musie
Composed by Mr. :•• O R : i ,
•„* The Extraordinart Reputation of this Theatre once acquired for the Product i m ' Historical Dramas, and the unprecedent success which attended
their pertormance. has induced the New Lessee to decide on making that specie.-ot
• rtainment a staple commodity ol the Establishment, blending
instruction with amusement, and drawing both from the Heroic and Chivalrous portions olour National Annuals, it will be her care not to mislead the
youthful mind or offend trie more matured, by preventing our Glorious Chronicles to mere Dramatic Fable, but by a careful study to poutray the Real
Cnaractcr and events of the Periods Represented to place truth (truthfully but Magnificently Attired) before her patrons.

| 3 h V O V H E P U B L I C !! J

MR. joroNCRiErr's
New Drama, announced last Week, called

JACK SHEPPARD! OR, THE PROGRESS OF GRIME j
In Fite Parts, and Twenty Scenes, founded on M r . A I N S W O R T H ' s Popular Novel of the same name ; being now in full preparation, will be
immediately produced. The courteous acquiescence ot the Author of the original work to its Dramatization, and the aid afforded by the matchless illustrations of the celebrated CRUIKSHANK, together with a powerful and deeply exciting interest of the work itself; exceeding as it does in graphic force, truth,
terrible affect, and continuity of story, even the best productions of '* the inimitable* JBOZ," fully warrant the supposition that this Drama will prove superior
for thrilling incident, strength of character, variety and originality of detail, aided as they will be by scenic etfect, novelty of costume, historical reminiscence,
domestic delinaation, and number of persons engaged in the personification, fully equal, if not superior, to any production hitherto brought forward, either
in this, or any other Theatre; fully maintains tits acknowledged pre-eminence of the Victoria, in the days of the Jewess, and the many other Dramas for
which it shone so unrivalled.
Stripped of all the fallacies which have usually invested representations of this nature, and displaying with striking fidelity, but without offending the
most fastidious, the dreadlul consequences inevitably attendant, sooner or later, on every deviation from the paths of virtue, this Drama will afford a
great moral lesson to the rising generation, such as can ouly bo enforced through the electrical, and direct medium of the Stage; at the same time it pieseuts
a vivid picture of the manners and customs of a by-gone age, ^improving, and instructing, while it amuses. Not an event in the original work,
proper for stage representation, or which may tend to the clear eluckl ition of the story, will be. found to have been .emitted. The only liberty taken with
the Novelist, having teen to heighten, and relieve the effects of his various scenes. And those whose avocations may not permit them to devote the time
necessary to read the whole of the original work, may here, at a sitting, have the whole presented to them in living reality, divested of all unnecessary
matter, effecting an economy of time, that is to many a point of much consideration. Every body MUST be acquainted with AlNSWORTH's life, adventures,
and escapes o! JA.CK, S H E P P A K . D , the far-famed housebreaker. And in this Drama, it is confidently trusted they will be seen with an effect, and
completeness not to be found elsewhere.

A TOM AND J E R R Y R O W OK T H E L A S T t : E N T U R Y .
The Coriothtstis of* 1715—Jack's fir«t breaking eat,

MOEBIEFn JACK SHEPPARB,

Scene 4 . — D A R K

The production of this extraordinary Drama last Monday Evening, the greatest effort ever made in the Theatrical World,
and it* glorious and triumphant Mttr.M having been wltnaaned by upwards often thousand persons during the past week, and its
proud wperiority acknowledged by the whole of the Public Press, the high gratification of Mr. Ainsworth, on *hoae fine Work
it is founded, no flatteringly expressed by L E T T E R , both to the Dramatizer and the Lessee, AFTEK HAVING A C T U A L L Y
W I T N E S S E D ITS KBPRESKNTATION, need not here be further dwelt upon.
T h e entire approbation expressed by that Gentleman, and numerous other influential persons whose praise i* the
Dr.iiwtizer's best reward, at the selection he has made of the various scene* occurring in the original Work, and the universal
Mtisfaction of the public in general, have conlrmed the Oramatizer in the correctness of his judgment.
Whatever he might
have gained by catering to vitiated, morbid, and unhealthy minds, he did not conceive he was justified in bringing upon the
Stage any representation of scenes that from their holy nature should ever beheld sacred; nor did he deem the present time
a fit season for the exhibition of the horrors of INS A NITY.
Having conducted the guilty Hero of the Drama to the certain reward of crime, and rendered due justice to designing villany,
he has thought it best to draw the curtain on a moral, and shut out frun further example the brutalizing minutk of that punish!
ment which affects the exit at the final goal. The reiterated cheers, and loud acclamations of satisfaction,and delight, which every
evening has crowned the labours of the Dramatizer, and the uuiverrd call after the fall of the curtain, for the reappearance of
the principal Actors to receive from the Audience the further testimony of their unalloyed commendation will at once evince the
•access of the Dramatizer, and the ability of tfi « • by .v!io<e <jrl i id u l e its that su-jcess h»s baenso completely crowned.
Extracted almost literally from Mr Aim worth's great Work the only alterations being those absolutely necessary for Stage
effect and relief. It is only doing justice to the matchless talents of that gifted writer, and the great Dramatic power displayed
throughout the original Work to say. ihat for breathless and untiring in erest, infinite variety, strength of character, knowledge
of life, truth to nature, anduniiy, and clearness of story, this Drama will be found to equal if not to exceed any Drama of a
domestic historical nature, ever yet produced upon the Stage, and as the resources of no Theatre but the Victoria permitted the
representation of the early part of the story so necessary to the clear understanding of the after part, owing to the extraordinary extent of Stage, and magnitude of machinery required for the full display of the iremendioxs Hurricane of JT03, on the
River Thames, and its appalling effects on Old Loudon Bridge, with its houses, enormous starlings, &c., at no other Theatre can
a perfect dramatization ol Ainssvorth's Jack Sheppard ho witnessed,

On MONDAY, Nov. 4 , 1 8 3 9 , d u r i n g t h e w e e k , &] t i l l f u r t h e r notice
Will be presented, for the TH1RTEN TH TIMES, an entirely new domestic Drama, of interestk fact, in FIVE PARTS, with New Music, Scenery, Diessei)
and Decorations, founded on Mr. AINSWOKTH'S Popular Romance, called

JACK S&HEPPARD!

MOJrCMMBWWS

JACK

Though the crowded audiences that every night fill I he Victoria Theatre to the very ceiling, to witness its most extraordinary
and exciting Drama of J a c k . S h e p p a r d , together with the united testimony of the whole of the Public Press to its Triumphant Success, and Superiority, renders anything further than the simple announcement of its continued representation completely
unnecessary, yet injustice to the H r o i n a t l z e r , and the various PERFORMERS and A R T I S T S of the Establishment; the
L K S S K K feels herself called upon not to let the present opportunity pass without making a few remarks on the zeal and
ability to which she is so much indebted.
Without at all wishing to detract from the various excellencies of rival productions, an inviduousness she would seduously
avoid, she may be permitted to point out, that at the V I C T O R I A T h e a t r e a N o n e can the ROMANCE of JACK
S H E P P A R O be seen Completely Represented. The Dramatuer had too great a respect for the powerful talents of the unrivalled Writer, to whose fine work he was indebted for his Materials, to allow of his departing in any important degree from his
original, he has commenced his Drama with the commencement of the Romance, which the limited resources of other Theatres
would not permit them to do. and through the medium of Five Distinct Farts, has conducted the story in a lucid and continuous
manner to the very close of the Work, omitting no incident of consequence at ail necessary for the progress of the story : he has
traced bis Her- from his Infancy, through his Childhoed, Youth and Manhood, to his final close, and though he has thought proper
to draw the Curtain over the brutalizing spectacle of a Pu'rlic Kxecuiien, he has not departed from Truth, nor defeated the ends
of Poetical, and all oilier justice, but has consigned his Hero to thsit Gibbet his crimes so richly merited, an example that cannot
be without its effect, rendering as it does, a striking moral lesson to the rising generation.
In the Palmy Days of the V I C ' T O H l M . , those days to which it is now happily restored, this Theatre universally allowed
to be the best constructed for the different purposes of Sight and Sound, of any House in Europe, was celebrated for its various
bold and astounding scenic ert'eets, and the public; attention is now fearlessly challenged to decide if in its present most ASTONISHING and KLKCTRICAL REPRESENTATION of the G R E A T H U R R I C A N E , on the River THAMES, during the
Night of the 26th Nov. 1703, the Artists of the Theatre luve not eqnallcd, and even surpassed all previous efforts of a like nature.
The various DlORAMlC EFFECTS of this most Memorable CONVULSION of N A T U R E , when as the Great Ramancist describes it, "Steeples toppled and towers reeled, beneath the fury of the blast. Trees were torn up by the roots ; and many
Houses levelled to the grOOnti while others were unroofed, the leads of the Churches being ripped off and shrivelled up like rolls
of parchment'' * * * " And all was darkness, horror, confusion, ruin, men flying- from their tottering habitations, and returning
so them scared by greater dangers, and the end of the world seemed at hand." The«e effects are displayed with fearful fidelity
and together with the appalling fury of the Elements on O L D L O W I M I r ? R l t I I » < « f C , covered as it then was with Houses
from one end to i he other, PRESENTIAV
THE APPEARANCE
OF A STREET
ACROSS THE THAMES must be seen
to be credited. The astonishment and delight of the audience testified en each display by loud and repeated acclamations is the
best witness of its cxtraordidnry excellence.
With these advantages of Suwy and Illustration, and the singularly felicitous combination of Talent, perfect in every particu.
lar, by which the whole of the Dramatis Persona) ore supported, the Lessee has great pleasure in announcing the Drama of JACK
S H E P P A R D . or, the PROGRESS
OF (RIME,
FOR CONTINUED
REPRESENTATION

0FMD9TS OF THE PRESS.
On Saturday evening we visited this Theatre to -witness one dramatie
version of tech Shtpimrd.
The house has for many years been an
ill-starred fabric, and chiefly from the conduct ef its managers, we apprehend, had latterly declined into bad odour with the public, from which it
la now, we believe, on the high road for emancipation if the present fair
leasee prosecutes the track in which she has started. The architectural
construction of t h e building is t h c best in Umdon, and perhaps, second
t o none In Europe for t h e purposes for which it was designed.
Mr. Braham, whose immense experience ought t o give weight t o his
expressed judgment, declared in its original structure that it was the best
theatre In which he had ever sung for the vibration and judicious
reflection of sound, and that he could always perform with less etertion
and more satisfaction t o himself in it than tit any other place of amusement at which he was in the habit of appearing. Since this opinion by
the talented veteran had been expressed, unskilful hands, under pretest of
decoration, has made many bung'ing inroads on the carefully harmonised plans of the architect; but these have all happily been superseded
under t h e present management, and the interior of t h e house has been
restored to its pristine formation, and now may be looked upon as a
monument of the profound scientific acqniremc ts and t h e taste of the
late Mr. Cabanel, who planned entirely and superintended the whole
building. It is now besides most elegantly decorated ; it is clean, lijht,
and combines every accommodation tit for an audience of every rank.
W e have been led into these remarks from a recollection of what it was
within a few years, the dirty, dingy, poverty-striken like place, sufficient
to frighten any one of ordinary susceptibility from ever being induced t o
pay it a second visit. But with regard t o the main object of the play of
Jack Sheppard, we have in the first pl«ce t o remark that it has been
dramatised by Moncrieff, an author who, if he were burned for dealing in
abort meMv fc> »«*'» mmuns, woiita most assuredly lie ft man sacrificed
for that of wi i he has never been chargable
He h a s always the notion
of giving the ,,eople their full peck and a handful over; but if this tie his
besetting sin, h e has many redeeming qualities as a manufacturer of such
pieces aa Jack Sheppard; be has had more practice than any other playwright, and his judgment has been amply tested in the many successful
efforta of his skill that long have been, and still remain before the
public. H e has taken a few liberties with t h e text of the novelist, but
not more than was necessary to render it subservient t o stage effect.
He has displayed vast discrimination and tact in hii selection of the scenes
that make complete and intelligible the fable of the plot; and, condensed
»a it is now, lie has made one busy succession of incidents well defined,
and calculated t o maintain an uninteirupted interest which never once
flags. "We have little hesitation in hazarding an avowal of our impression
that it will be universally admitted t o be the best of t h e many versions of
the subject that has been produced at any of the rival establishments.
Not the least of its recommendations, is the care and calculation that has
been thrown into the preparation by whieh the combined talents of t h e
whole company have been brought to Itear so efficiently. Thc hero,
Jafh Sheppttrdmr
Harding) is performed in a very superior style. He
has studied carefully, and is eiceeedingly effective in thc poriratu,c of the
reckless burgular; his readings ore given with considerable judgment, nnd
the points of thc author brought o u t with a quietness and a t i possession
notalways t o be met with on minor stages. He preserves with the skill of
an artist the versatility of the manner of the man In his different assumed
humours, and passes to the pathetic with a freedom and truth of delineation that seems very much like nature. Jonathan Wild, Mr Hicks, on
whom much of the business depends, is the tiest thing we have ever seen
this gentleman do. He has shaken oft" that restlessness whieh some years
ago he was prone t o , and now the repose which lie gives t o his acting
enhances his value immensely; he affords us a very graphic picture of
what we could suppose Jonathan t o have been. Mr. Kneebone, Mr. Wanders,
It the very heau ideal of the City ?illy tradesman, aristocratic libertine.
He dresses the part t o the very pink oi perfection and is richly humouruus
in the dialouge. Caliban, Mr. Sloan, although, in point of fact, a subordinate part is so closely hit off as tn become in the hands of this actor,
a feature that stands prominently forward.
Sir Rowland Tremckard,
Mr. Simpson, appeared t o us to be of t h a t description which actors designate a up-hill, or rather unprofitable character, but Mr. Simpson did all
for It thirt could be expected in drawing upon it a share of attcnticn and
applause. Edgworih Best and Afr«, Maggolt, Miss George and Mrs.
Brlndal, at the expense of being thought ungallant in paying a compliment,
we must aay, looked their parts to the life, and infused all t h e archness
that t h e gay decievers required. The other female characters were admirably sustained by Mesdames Gurney and Howard, and France and
Mi*s Stoker, The cast is so very numerous that we must pass o?er
several that else deserve to be noticed; but as a whole we are bound in
justice to say that the performance of the piece is highly creditable to t h e
house. The painting and scenic effects are produced on the most expensive scale—they arc splendid and they are characteristic ; but so many of
them are there that we can only bestow upon them one sentence of general approbation. 'J he orche»tra, under the leadership of M r . Webb, will
be sure t o command tbe notice of visitors. The house was literally
crowded t o t h e ceiling; the boxes were filled with a fashionable audience;
in fact, the house, in its frequenters, seemed t o have undergone an
entire change—it was impossible t o suppose abetter conducted assemblage,
or an audience that appeared more highly delighted. The-«hoiuic resounded
with cheers at the fall of the curtain, and Mr. Harding being called lor
appeared, led on by Mr, Hicks, w h o shared with him t h e congratulation,
of the crowded benches. Cf««fe Oli'sef concluded t h e entertainments of
the evening, whieh bad eloted I o n - before twelve, o'clock, Mmting AA,

-

Dispatch,

At the Vieloiia Theatre a clever but awfully lengthy
version ha» been produced, the acting was generally
respectable ; llnrditig wants force for J S O K , but his performance was n careful one, and he did not out Herod.
Herod; the HI t KSKIN of Howard was an effort of talent,
but the author hus infused no fun into him, the humour of the
piece heitig appearetrUy intrusted to Manners, who looked
KNKEBOKE splendidly—his dressing was perfection, aad
did all the part pemitted bim. Mrs. Howard, who represented Alas, SHBPPAB.D, is an actress of great taste (a rare
ijiialiiieation).; site depicted the lovely but heart-broken
woman admirably. The Bufferer, whose sense of her own
errors scarcely permitted her to speak, was more truthfully
presented by this lady than wo can conceive it to be, or to
Have been, by any actress of tbe day. The house was crowded to excess,ami the applause at the fall of the curtain w*.
loud and long continued.*' Sunday
Ttmn,
<• Moncriefl's version of J a OK SJHEPPAHD, is not onlyjthe
test, BUI BY F A R the best «e have seen', it embodies jthe
lending incidents of, the romance, placing them all on an
intelligible and dramatic form." PARTHJSKON,Oet. 26, l%@,

vrfB UOAinAY # Nov. 18, I8&1L d u r i n g t h e w e e k , A t i l l f a r t h e r n o t i c e
Wilf b e fjefrffiM. tot tllui T X e u t v - u x t h Times, an' entirely new domestic Drama, of interest fc fact, in F I V E P A R T S , wftli N e w Music Semerv Dresses

' ™^-p** , l
'

JACK SHEPPARH!

The W e e . »ramati»e«l a n d produced solely b yM r , MONCRIEPF.
The appearance o f ' Jack Sheppard ' at so many different houses in the course of one evening, was only to be expected from
lO accomplished a Cracksman as himself, and the Crowds of Persons that have flocked to the Victoria Theatre, with the view of
getting a Peep at Him, might in a less well-built frabric have made him prove really a Housebreaker! but the Theatre having
fortunately sustained no injury from the Press, but on the contrary having had its hold on public grounds made firmer by the R e port* of these who have Surveyed it, Jack has really become, in this particular instance, a House Maker ! I! The usual Ordinary
Account has been superceded by Extraordinary Account*. The pockets of half the population of the metropolis have been attacked by this notorious character, and deprived of a portion of their contents, and though they still Pursue him in the Prosecution of their desires that he shall be done justice to. The rogue nightly follows his career with impnnlty, and will, it is believed,
continue to do so through many sessions to come. The Best Judges have decided that the plea of an Alibi in the Victoria cannot
be stworfned there, though it may be in other houses, for that Jack's Veritable Appearance can be proved by myriads of witnesses I and both the Lessee and the Author can bear testimony on oath, to his having been found in the Treasury, with Considerable
Quantities of Money 1 which they fortunately secured. The utmost viligance is exercised that he -hall not ultimately escape the
jrjft reward of his var'ous daring acts. The Villain's Trial will re-commence this evening, and be continued through the Sittings
During the Week, Persons wishing to obtain places in the Gallery, the Witnesses Boxes, or on the Floor of the Court, are r e quested to Come Karly ! or they will mis* hearing the whole of the evidence gone through. Ketch the Idea/ a plea in arrest of
judgment, having been entered on the motion fbr final Suspension, and duly recorded. The Public are respectfully informed that
Jack Sheppard'- condemnation has been adjourned rim Die ! Leading Counsel for (be Prosecution. Mr, Sergeant Beverly,
Messrs. Hicks, Simpson, Minders, Burton, Moncrieff, Ac. the latter learned Gentleman being specially retained, with a Largo
F e e , from the Courts Above. Counsel lor the Defence, Messrs, Harding, Framplotu Sloaue, Howard, Ac. from the Courts
Below. Mesdms. Brindal and George, Queen's Counsel.
N . B . — T h e Witnesses attending the Floor of the Conn are requested to take care, that they have the customary Shilling along
with Iheir Supo-nas, or the proceedings will not be legal Th-j Court will be opened and Proceedings commence at the usual time.
P.S.—The Nosegay thrown to the Desperado, when he was Called Forward to receive judgment at the Close of the Proceedings
last Monday Evening, will be kept for the occasion for which it was doitbtlcssly intended.

THJE GAMING

HOUSE !

Th« Winner and the Loser —exultation and dispair—the Eve of the Wedding, and the lost Jewe1s~-the innocent arrested—the
W«dd?ng Morn—advice of Old age—moral lesson on Gaming—pledge to renounce i —departure of the Wedding Party—awful
disclosure* in their absence—return of the New Married Pair—the Stolen Jewels discovered «<n theNeck of the Wife—the
Husband Arrested—the agony & Death of the Father who invokes a I I I ' I N C * C l s R S K U P O N H I S S O N .
I ' A I I T 2 » d , a lapse of 15 Years.
Progre** of Gaming—its effects—domestic happiness destroyed—crime committed—Forged Biiic—danger of arrest—fetal effects
of unfounded Jealousy—

The Gamester becomes a Murderer I
P A R T 3 r d , another period of 15 Years is supposed to have elapsed between the Second and Third Part*-

LION

traveller—arrival of a Stranger

INTERIOR & THE HUT ON THE RED MOUNTAIN

he w»* a Guide across the Mountain. .arrival of a French Officer whom not recognirJng as his Son he attemps to Rob—his flight

Lover* united—peace restored— ' a kind good night to all S H A K B S P E A K

The Friar's Bridge—I'ov st and Castle of the Wolf. By Sunrise.
*«* "Once upon a time, a Country Girl lived in a Village, who was the sweetest little creature that ever was seen, her fathernaturally loved her with
excessive fondness, and her Grandmother doated on her still more. Thegood woman had made for her a pretty little red-coloured hood which so much
became the littla girl, that every one called her Little Red Riding Hood.
T h e C o u n t a n d t h e C o t t a g e « t r l . . " H e i t I I I d l u f f H o o d b e w a r e , t h e W o i r ! " . . Arrival of the Travellers, .the Spell
begins to work . .strange coincidences and Goblin Fears. .The trap to catch Gwynette.. The illness of her Grandmother.
*«* " One day her Mother having made some Cheesecakes, said to her, ' Go my Child, and see how your Grandmother does, for I hear she is ill ; carry
her lome of these Cakes and a little pot of Butter.' Little Red Riding Hood straight set out with a basket, filled with the cakes and the pot of Butter, for
her Grandmother's house was in a village a little way off."

ftm*d *nd meriting Drmtrut of . l a c k S h e p p a r d , and the present G o r g e o u . P a n t o m i m e , and in order atiH fu-tfaer
to sustain tfce high reputation this Theatre formerly had, and now again happily has. for the representation of S p e c t a c l e , of
e x t r a o r d i n a r y e f f e c t & m a g n i t u d e , for whieh its resources are to uniquely calculated, the whole of the Artists of
the Establishment have been for some time past busily engaged in preparations for an K n t i r e l y N e w a n d I n t p r e M i v e
D r a m a which she flatters herself will be found to exceed in unprecedented extent, original and exciting interest! powerf/n* incident ! verted combination o$ attraction, and a s t o u n d i n g D e n o u e m e n t , all that have hitherto proceeded it.

will be loat in presenting it, with ail th. advantages of New Music, Scenery, Dresses, Decorations, end Gigantic Machinery, to the
supporters of the Victoria. It may be enough, that she begs to state in addition, that this g r e a t N o v e l t y i n * h . i D r a m a t i c W o r l d will be th. production »f

The s.Mwt of this Drams is token from an Historical tact—the Culprit not being executed, is the cause why it is not Recorded in the page* of tfc. Ne-^wte
Calendar; for the information of the curious, the Drnmatizer refers them to a work, entitled • Chronicles of Olden Times, where a particular description
wilt be found of the situation of Kosevffle Mansion.—This fatal occurrence too* place near the Romantic Town of St. Alton's—the Cioik Home stood for
many years after, but being untenanted, rapidly fell into decay, ai A was at length pulled down—The Talei of a Village A!e House, have oiten provnd a aonree
of pleasure to the Traveller, but none aie told more frequently than the Murder of tha Mansion.

THRITHK.

The subject of this Drama is taken from an Historical Fact—the Culprit not being executed, ia the cause why it is not RecordsH i« the pace, of the Newgate
Calender; for th* infarmatfon of the curious, the Oraaatttlzer refers them t . a w.rk, entitled " Chronicles of Oitten Timet, where a particular description
will be i.iund of the situation of Koacvttte Mansion.—TW» fittal occurrence took place near the Romantic Town of St. Alban's—t»e Cloik House stefd for
• n a y year, after, but being untenanted, rapidly felt into decay, at d was at lea-th pulled down.—The Tales of u Villa** Ale House, have often prosed a sourct
«f piemm* to the Tra-ett*r, but M M are told saore frequently than the M urder of the Mansion.

This Romantic Drama rests on the Supposition that a German Student, had proceeded t<i far in his abstruse studies, as to m a b .
himself master of the minusia of Causation, and possess the secret of bestowing animation uv,«n lifeless matter, and succeeds i n

A N I M A T I N G A N AUTOMATON,
T h e D R K A O r i L i P E C T R G of a HUMAN

FORM,

comes a Demon, and acts upon impulse only —and Frankenstein has scarcely completed his work, than he repents the Impious

Monster attempts the Life of his Maker1

THE

The object of this Piece, it will be perceived is to hold out a strong Moral Lesson to the Rising
Generation, by exhibiting in the most appalling colours, the ruinoui danger attendant on the
slightest deviation, from the paths of rectitude.

Second Week of M O N C R I B F F ' S Successful Historical Play

THE TRIBUTE QF ONE HUNDRED VIRGINS.
MT The breathless interest and deep excitement created by Mr. MONCRIEFF** n e w grand historical Plajr, the TRIBUTE ef ONS BTJNDRED VIRGINS, and the, rapturous acclamations of applause
bestowed by the erewded audiences w h a have honored It w i t h their presence, during the past w e e k ,
having been fully equal to those eestowed on t h e JEWESS, and other celebrated productions of th#
same Author, imperatively call tipea the Proprietor to s o m . s a . e i t i repetition every evening, t i l l
further notice. The novelty and force of the situations In this Drama, the energy and passion of its
characters and language, and its tendency to call forth all those feelings that define and enoble
human nature, fully bear lout t h e high reputation this Theatre has so long enjoyed, for the preeminence of Its productions in this class of t h e dramatic art, and w i l l be th«t best -warranty of
t h e superiority of its future offerings of the same kind to the patronage of the public.

On MONDAY, May lHtb, Itt-IO, and d u r i n g t h e W e e k , will he presented (for
the 7ih Tits**) uu entirety Original Grand Historical Drama, founded on facts, with New Music,
Scenery, DTOMOI and Decorations, called The

The Annual tribute of One Hundred Virgins, *o long paid by the Spanish Mouarchs of Castile to the
Moorish Caliphs of Cordova, by virtue of a treaty, entered*into by FERDINAND the 4th, particularized
by several of the Olden Spanish Chroniclers, forms the subject of the present Drama, several heart
alirring incidents, of which, are to be found in the Romances and Legends of that |>eriod.

I ^ T * The Engagement of those Talented Artists, M i s s V I N C E N T and M r Jf I I U N N ,
necessarily obliges the Proprietor to postpone for the present, the repetition of the, piquant historical
Drama of the t M J E E N o f a D A Y ; o r , T h e T w o I n f a n t a s , which has been haikd
throughout with such Universal Cheering, and Boars of Laughter', to be resumed on the termination
of the present arrangements.
The Lessee has to announce thai the Artistes of the Establishment have heed actively engaged in the
production of an EXTRAORDINARY NOVELTY in Two Acts, which will be presented
for the First time on MONDAY, May, 25th, comprising an Original Local Drama, ofThrilling
Interesf, founded on a work at present engrossing the attention of all classes of society.—It will be
produced with the most scrupulous adherence to Scenery, Dresses, and Decorations.
Families may be Supplied with Private Boxes or Seats in the Dress Circle, on application to the Box
Book Kieper from 11 till So'Clock.

D U N N , «*« JftyiM "Jim Grow."
On TUESDAY, IMay »©th, 1 8 4 0 , a n d d u r i n g t h e W e e k , the Evening's
Entertainments will commence with (First Time) an entirely Original Domestic Drama, in TWO
ACTS, selected from the popular work by "BOZ," called

T H E

CLOC K 1

'• How often have I sat in the long winter evenings feeling society in its cricket-voice, how often in the
anmmer twilight, when my thoughts have wandered back to a melancholy past, have its regular
whisperings recalled them to the calm and peaceful present; how often in the dead tranquillity of
night has its bell broken the oppressive silence, and seemed to give me assurance that the old clock
was still a faithful watcher at my chamber door! !My easy-chair, my desk, my ancient furniture, my
very books, I can scarcely bring myself to love even these last, like my old clock."
A Brothers Crimes.. The Detection—The Quarrel—The One Witness—The Story of Revenge-

F e a r !—Remorse I!—Agony!

11

TEEEB CONF E AG R AT I O JV!

The Interior &M a ster Humphreys'

"An old house, which in bygone days was a famous resort for merry roysterers ano peerless ladies, long
tinee departed ; a silent shady place, with a paveet court-yard so full of echoes, that sometimes I am
tempted to believe that faint responses to the noises of old times linger there yet, and that these ghosts
of sound haunt my footsteps as 1 pace it up and down ."—The Love Story—The Alarm—The Lost Child!

S Y N O P S I S O P T H E S C E N E R Y - P A R T 1st.

The Interior sMaster Humphreys'

"An old house, which in bygone flays was a famous resort for merry roysterers and peerless ladies, long
since departed ; a silent shady place, with a paved court-yard so full of echoes, that sometimes I am
tempted to believe that faint responses to the noises of old times linger there yet, and that these ghosts
of sound haunt my footsteps as I pace it up and down."—The Love Story—The Alarm—The Lost Child!

Olil>

!"<»lli>\H,IIT>

TUB

GAAIDEN//

"He thought of her all day, and dreamed of her all mgVit long ; he treasured up her every word and
gesture, and had a palpitation of the heart whenever he hea rd her foot-step or her voice."~The Lovers—
The avowal—The Prom ised Bride.

MASTER

HUMPHREY'

"This is the last night I have to live, and I will set down the naked truth without disguise. I was never
a brave man, and had always been from my childhood of a secret sullen distrustful nature. I speak of
myself as if I had passed from the world, for while I speak this my grave is digging, and my name is
written in the black book of death."—The Confession—The A s s a s s i n — T h e Bride.
T
H
E
MM MBZ MM
€ 3 M L ' ML M L MM J E M R I J
"But all that night, waning or in my sleep, the same thoughts recurred and the same images retained
possession of my brain. I had ever before me the old dark murky rooms—the gaunt suits of mail with
their ghostly silent air—the faces all awry, grinning from wood and stone—the dust and rust worm
that lives in wood—and alone in the midst of all this lumber and decay and ugly age, the beautiful
child in her gentle slumber, smiling through her light and sunny dreams."

Tableau.—T HE

DREAMER.

T H E FLIGHT AND PURSUIT.

THE C L O

I

" How often have 1 sal in the long winter evenings feeling society in its cricket-voice, how often in the
summer twilight, when my thoughts have wandered back to a melancholy past, have its regular
whisperings recalled them to the calm and peaceful present; how often in the dead tranquillity of
night has its bell broken the oppressive silence, and seemed to give me assurance that the old clock
was still a faithful watcher at my chamber door! My easy-chair, my desk, my ancient furniture, my
very books, I can scarcely bring myself to love even these last, like my old clock."
A Brothers Crimes.. The Detection—The Quarrel—The One Witness—The Story of Revenge—
R

F e a r !—JRemorse

LOOK AT THE CLOCK. BY MR. Ill ANDERS.
The whole to concludo with a New Romantic Diania, with entire New Scenery, Dresses, ami Appointments, called The

" A n old house, which in bygone days was a famous resort for merry roysterers and peerless ladies, long
since departed ; a silent shady place, with a paved court-yard so full of echoes, that sometimes 1 am
t e m p t e d t o believe that faint responses to the noises of old times linger there yet, and that these ghosts
of sound haunt my footsteps as 1 pace it up and down."— The Love Story—Tlic Alarm—The Lost Child'

MID i\1l THE MOM,

OLD LONDON '.--(MIDNIGHT)

" J e r k i n s and quarter-staves are in the streets again, the nightly watch is set, the rebel, sad and lonely
in his Tower dungeon tries to sleep and weeps for home and children."—The Brawl—Rescue of the
Unknown—The Recognition and the T h r e a t .

A H C t U M K I U T . — V K R U Z Z I has devoted his Daughtei to the Church, in g-atitude lor deliverance from imminent peril*; at the
given time the M"nk rl.tmi her, her Lover resents the Injustice, denying the Father's right to such disposal; in the Struggle he
loses his Dagger, which the Monk secretes. To appease the wrottg done to the Church, Vonv/.i bestows te*els to a considerable
amount, and delivers them |p person at the neigbotirhig Convent, oil his return at niuht he In mimWcd by Assassins in the pay of
the Monk; the Lover's Dagger is I'ouud in his body ; llortcnza, the Daughter, solemnly swears over her Father's corse, t . tr»ce
his Murderers.
Lconiini, her Lover, is accused of, and arrested for the Murder, and confined in the cells of the Inquisition;
Frank, an English servant of Leontini, accideutly overhears tlie conversation of the Assassins, speaking relative to the comni*siouof the Murder, he informs hfs Mistress, site, disguised as a Galley Slave seeks the Murderers, introduces herself to them «s
an Associate, prevails on them to assist her in the robbery of her own Caslollo, where having the.n secure, the Offi :ers of the
Inquisition, to whom she had written, arrive, the Monk is identified as the Instigator of the Murder, Leontini proclaimed Innocent,
and the Monk finally slabbed by Hortenza.

EXTERIOR
OF THE OLD CURIOSITY SHOP I
"One of those receptacles for old and curious things which seem to crouch in odd corners of this town
and to hide their musty treasures from the Public eye in jealously and distrust."—Agony and Suspense
—Master Humphrey—Stratagem of the Cavalier—The Drunken Servant and the Lordly Lover.

I N T E R I O R of the OLD CURIOSITY SHOP.
" T h e r e were suits of mail standing like ghosts in armour here and there, fantastic carvings brought
from monkish cloisters, rusty weapons of various kinds, distorted figures in China and wood and iron
and ivory ; tapestry and strange furniture that might have been designed in dreams."

Gardens of the C A S T E L L O , and TOMB of Y E R E Z Z I .
An Apartinc-ur in (lie t'lfttcllo

« How often have I sat in t h e long winter evenings feeling society in its cricket-voice, how often in the
summer twilight; when m y t h o u g h t s have wandered back to a melancholy past, have its regular
whisperings recalled them to "the calm and peaceful present; how often in the dead tranquillity 0 f
night has its bell broken the oppressive silence, and seemed to give me assurance that the old clock
was still a faithful watcher a t m y chamber door! My easy-chair, my desk, my ancient furniture, m y
very books, 1 can scarcely bring myself to love even these last, like m y old clock.
A Brother**. C r i m e s . . T h e Detection—The Quarrel—The One W i t n e s s - T h e Story ot Revenge—

After which an interesting Historical Drama, in 2 Acts, called

Rfvti DEATH DP
•MB

wBawmm

MJ WwmmmkWmWm mom tfllflfe

W

H

Or, The R o c k of St. H e l e n a I
This Dram* is founded on incidents which took place on the Island of St. Helena, and will be found to convey a faithful history of the character aad
.-..urtunes of that great man, whose powerful genius, and ambitious soal, led him triumphantly, from the rank of Lieut., till he became Gratia
->nffu»and Emperor of the French,
i t the head of his victorious army, he subdued nation after nation, and with fire and sword, bestrode tnum..ictly through ail the realms of the vast Continent. All Europe trembled at his power—England alone—" that water.walled bulwark, hedged ie
•th the main, whose foot spurns back the oceans roaring tide," resisted ail his efforts and finally subdued him on the Plains* of Waterloo:
The action commences from his- landing at St. Helena and concluding with his Death. Mr. GOMERSAL, whose identification of tins Great H H
•fies criticism, has kindly consented to appear in this character, for this night only.

To he follows I by an interesting Historical drama, in Two Acts, <allcH

THE DEATH OF

WAPOLEOiy •
Or, the MlacM ofMt

Helena.

This Drama is fu'indcd on incidents which took place on th» Island of St He' 'a* and will be fuuwj to convey a itiiliiul hiuory
of the character and misfortunes of that great nan, arbor, powfli-ftil geni;:.«, and 'miiiiious soul, led h?m Iriumpiiautly, from the
ra.k of Lieut., till ho became Urand L'ontit! and Emperor of the French. At the head of his victorious army, he subdued nation
after nation, and with tiro and sword, bestrode triumphantly through all the roilms ofll« vast Continent
All Europe irembh'd
at h i . power—England alone—" that water-walled bulwark, hedged in with the main, whose foot -purns back the oceans roaring
tide," restated all his efforts and finally subdued him on the Putins of Waterloo.
The action commences from his landing at St. Helena and cjncluding with his Death. Mr. GOMERSAL; whose identification
of thia Great Man defies competition, has kindly consented (o a >pear in this character, for this night only.

!
!"
the miKie*«tts and Repeated Enquiries made for the Revival of
MoKCfttBvVa highly successful Drama of JACK S H E P P A R D originally prodaced at
this Theatie, and universally pronounced !>y the Public Press, to be the beat Dramatic
Version that has appeared of AINSWOHTH'S far-famed and popular Work : The Man*
ager respectfully informs the Public that, ever anxious to meet their wishes, it will be re-produced
with even more than all its original effects, this Evening, MONDAY, October 26th. An earnest desire
atili further to merit the encouragement of the Patrons of this Theatre by the production only of
Novelties, has alone prevented the contemporaneous appearance of this Drama with those on the same
subject at other Establishments, hut in obedience to the reiterated call of the Public voice, it is now presented to them with the single omission, on account of its great length, of the prefatory first part. It
has been too much the custom with Revivals, to bring them forward shorn of their pristine attraction* ;
but such will not be the case in this instance, as no pains nor expense will be spared to do justice to so
established a favourite. Most of the original representatives, will appear again in their old characters,
among whom will be found Mr. BURTON.Mr. BENDER, Mr. KING, Mr. SEARLE,Mr. CONWAY,
Mrs. FRANCE, and Mr. HARDING as the Hero JACK SHEPPARD. The excellence of these
Artists will be the best guarantee for their renewed exertions on this occasion, while the merits of the
Ladies and Gentlemen who are among the new accessions to the Company, will be the best warrant?
that no loss will be sustained by the Public in the changing of the other parts, which will be represented
by th«m. In addition to this, the Manager must not forget to state, that notwithstanding thr arduous
exertions Mr HICKS has to undergo in "THE WIZARD OF THE WAVE," the Drama will be
still further strengthened by his having most handsomely and cheerfully consented to appear again en
the same evening in his old part of JONATHAN WILD, a Character he has made so peculiarly Ms
own ; this disregard to personal convenience to add to the gratification of the Andienee, while it calls
for the best thanks of the Management, will not be unappreciated by the Public, who are ever ready to
reward any attempt made for their approbation.—Altogether an unnsual treat may be expected hv the
combination of THE WIZARD OF THE WA VH" with MACK SHEPPAKD," two sued powerful
and extensive Dramas, never having before, it is submitted, been produced together on the same
Evening at any Theatre whatever.

HKEWIM BENEFIT
OF THE Y E T E R A N H A R L E Q U I N

( For 25 Tears the Principal Harlequin of the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden)
Who begs leave most respectfully to announce to his Friends, and the Public in general, that at the
suggestion of many of his former Patrons he intends taking his - F a r e w e l l B e n e f i t at the
above Elegant Theatre

On T H U R S D A Y . NOT. 2 6 , 1 8 4 0 ,
On which occasion the Evening's Performances will consist of several Favourite Pieces, and in
addition to the Excellent Company of the above Establishment he will be assisted by a Host af First
Rate Talent, from th*e PrincipalLondon Theatres; among whom he has the honour to announce

HIr . T . P . COOKE,

Who has in the mostHandsome and Friendly manner given his Valuable Services. Full particulars
announcing the Gentlemen who have in the most kind manner Volunteered their Services to act as
Committee will be duly announced in a few days.
